review:
A mild recommend when it goes on sale; you can get it for less than a dollar. If not, avoid; it's not recommended.

It's mostly serviceable, but not without its flaws. The story is your typical supernatural, mystery fare with a nonsensical premise coupled with dreary, extraneous exposition that frequently have no meaningful impact to the plot and deadpan dialogue/voice-acting. The HOGs are decent; hitboxes can sometimes be a bit wonky but serviceable for the most part. Minigames are alright too; most are quite intuitive on what you need to do to solve them, bar a few which are extremely tedious (clear solution but requires a lot of legwork to get to it). A lot of backtracking but no map; some interactions only appear after certain triggers so you will spend a decent amount of time checking locations.

Mildly recommended.

It feels pretty polished, has a clean interface, decent hidden object scenes and a low asking price. Unfortunately, the overall story is decent but there are a few questionable scenes, bad character actions, silly requests made of the player, etc. The voice acting is not very good either and there are issues with the voice volumes for some characters making you have to read the subtitles to understand what is being said. Skip this one.

review:
Like every other HOG in existence, this one deals with the supernatural. You play as an ex-priest who's been called to his brother's estate to help with your niece's possession. At least playing as a man is unique to these kinds of games.

It's an OK game: the HOPs are the right amount of difficult and the minigames are challenging, but there are some things that just make this game not worth recommending:

1. The annoying, repetitive background noises (e.g. flies buzzing, clocks ticking, etc...)
2. The horrible voice acting.
3. How slowly everything loads. You can't do anything else while your previous action is loading, and it is SLOW.
4. It's just... not that great of a story.

If you're an achievement hunter I guess it's worth it (only $0.99 on sale) but overall it's just not very good.

review:
I'd go with a mixed review. 

The story itself is pretty good, but seemed a bit rushed and jumbled towards the end.
The hidden object scenes and puzzles were pretty easy. Which isn't bad in itself, but if people want to be challenged more, it would be a bad trait. 
The voice acting is...pretty bad. There's one or 2 characters that seemed like they just dragged someone off the street last minute.
Some of the ambient sound effects got...a little annoying. Mostly at the end. 
It's a very short game...took me less than 2 and a half hours to complete without hints or skips. Yet at the same time, as others have said, very tedious.

I'd recommend if you were getting is as part of a bundle.

review:
I‚Äôd probably go with a mixed review if I could. The story wasn‚Äôt that good, but the gameplay wasn‚Äôt too bad. I‚Äôll go with a thumbs up for the interactive map with instant travel between locations.

I thought this game was kind of easy. One thing took a little getting used to though. A lot of times you can‚Äôt use an object directly from your inventory. For example, one of the puzzles involved chopping up food to make soup. You can‚Äôt use the knife while it‚Äôs in your inventory. You have to first find the right place for it and only then can you use it to chop. Instead of using the knife directly on the food, you have to place the knife in the right spot, which is slightly away from the food. The same pattern is repeated, so figuring this out helped a great deal with finishing the game. If you can‚Äôt use an object directly on another object, then try using it near the other object instead.

Some people had problems getting the achievement for Film Critic, but I was able to get it. I played the game straight through without changing any settings. Check the forums for more details.

review:
Colonial Africa setting is really good. It feels exotic and original. The game is older but the story is above average because you can really feel flow of the tale. There are some strange moments connected with changing of the place and inconsistendy but it fits the story. (Is it reality or not?) Minigames are too easy but made quite good. To my surprise HOS are funny despite the fact they are relatively easy and I enjoyed them. A lot of items but still not a pile a junk. Screens are not grey (a typical malady of older games), colorful enough and items are bigger. There is even option for wide monitor compensation.
My recomendation is YES for anybody. It is not a gem, the game is older and the gameplay is shorter but story is original, the graphics is quite good and you can spend a few hours in different world and enjoy most of the time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077378264', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 406, 'last_played': 1557125477}
review:
Barely recommended - This is a pretty mediocre hidden object game.  The story is set in Africa.  The main character is Jonathan, a former priest that has been summoned by his friend Michael to investigate whether Michael's daughter Jenny is possessed.  The basic story is an interesting premise but the execution is weak.  The voice acting for the narrator is OK, but it varies from bad to terrible for most of the other characters.  Things unwind in a contrived fashion and the player is given annoying tasks to complete to advance the story.   It takes about two hours to finish the game once.

I think the artwork for the locations and hidden object scenes is pretty decent.  The hidden object games themselves are above average - there are no bad clues.  The mini games are not especially challenging or difficult.

This game has Steam achievements.  You should be able to harvest them all in one play through but I ran into an issue and it took three tries to get the last one.  This issue is documented in the discussions for this title.

I give this game 5.5 out of 10.  Maybe buy it on sale if you really like hidden object games.  It isn't worth the full price.

review: ‚ÄúThe Saint‚Äù is a typical representative of the HOG genre, this one being slightly above the usual average. The story takes your character, a war veteran and ex-priest (this game is one of the few in the genre where the main protagonist is a man), to colonial Africa to visit your cousin, who is asking you for help with his daughter that is being possessed by a demonic entity. The game has relatively good graphics, and the hidden-object scenes are well designed; music is somewhat weaker, there is just one ambient melody, but it fits the atmosphere nicely. Gameplay is quite short, expect it to last not much longer than 2 hours, but at least the story is quite captivating (though the plot holes and illogical steps that are so prevalent in HOGs couldn‚Äôt be avoided...). A good game for Saturday afternoon relax, and at adequate price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015747676', 'num_games_owned': 2103, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 285, 'last_played': 1532915941}
review:
[b]In a nutshell:[/b]
On the whole, not terrible. I'm not sorry I played it, if that tells you anything. If you can deal with an obtuse storyline/script and spotty VOs (some good, some godawful), the HOGs and art are quite good. Puzzles are varied, but easy and hit and miss with quality. Decent enough as a ~3 hour time waster, or to grab a few extra achievements. 

[b]The Long Version:[/b]
Not gonna lie: parts of this game are pretty bad. But it's also not a total wash either. I went in expecting a complete cringe-fest after reading some of the negative reviews, but it was more tolerable than they make it seem. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Not many complaints, at least as far as gamebreaking issues go. I didn't run into any of those. The most awkward bit might be the jigsaw painting toward the beginning. Moving the pieces around is really annoying.

P&C item use makes sense for the most part, but [i]finding[/i] the item you need is really unintuitive in a couple of spots. The scene might require a specific item by name, but no matter where you look you can't seem to locate it. Or the scene just says "I don't have the item I need yet" but technically you do, and it's already in your inventory. The worst offenders are in the police station (the magnifying glass is in the multitool already in your inventory, not a separate item to find) and later on in the house when you're trying to break the seals (place the face coin on the seal with the skulls).

HOG scene art is nicely done and clutter items suit the scene.

Puzzles and minigames are varied but mostly easy, with a few totally mindless and unchallenging ones. There's a quick Reversi match toward the end though, which is not something you usually see in these games.

[h1]Story/Script[/h1]
On the whole, the concept is a solid idea: Demon gets trapped in magic book, magic book is used by person, demon escapes and makes said person's life miserable, goal is to stop and/or destroy demon and book. So far so good. 

Unfortunately the plotline is marred by haphazard, awkward, disjointed exposition and weird extraneous overly-complex-yet-vague details that don't add anything but window dressing. Why are you spending minutes at a time telling me XYZ if it either 1) has no bearing on the plot, 2) only ever gets mentioned once, or 3) could easily be omitted with zero change to the story structure? For example there's the whole war background and ex-priest thing. The PC could just as easily have been shown to have weird blackouts and stuff without being a priest. And the "war" feels completely shoehorned in for the sole purpose of telling a stereotypical "a bible stopped a bullet from hitting me and that's how I found god" backstory (which isn't even needed, because the priest bit isn't vital). And so on.

The script ricochets between passably good and so bad it makes me wonder if a preschooler wrote the dialogue. Some of it is just outright stupid, like when you first meet the cook and she asks you to fetch her some water, since she's too busy with Super Important Things‚Ñ¢ to make the apparently arduous trek to retrieve it from the water barrel. Which is, by the way, sitting [i]literally[/i] right behind her. It seems that going out of her way to turn around and fill up a jug to cook with would distract her too much from her duties as a chef...to, y'know, cook things. Then she asks you to go ahead and make the soup yourself, because apparently she's too busy even for that. I mean, come on. You just met the lady, and she's already having you do her chores. Oh, and your reward for making soup for the family? A bowl of soup. *fanfare and confetti* THEN when you bring that soup to the shoemaker, "all he has" to give you are a handful of nails. I was painfully reminded of the moronic task-reward system in [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/absurdlogic/recommended/429610/]The Emerald Maiden[/url]. Sure, a specific mundane item may advance the plot, but I could have just grabbed a bunch of nails from anywhere. It's not like I need a rare supercharged lithium ion battery for a dead smartphone and only one person in the whole country can get it on the black market. That would make sense for a fetch quest reward. Not soup and nails.

When you beat the game, before the credits roll, the art production just kinda...stops. Completely. Instead of the expected series of images showing where the characters ended up, all you get is a black screen with white text while your character narrates mechanically, like at the end of animal rescue shows where they tell you how Fido is now in a good home and plays in the yard every day. I really don't care if Jane is "growing like a weed". You barely get any chance to give a crap about her in the first place. There's no real explanation for the stuff that matters.

[h1]Voiceovers[/h1]
I'm setting aside a category here to specifically rag on the VO for the shoemaker you meet at the beginning. The other reviewers were not exaggerating. It's like the actor was a newbie who thought..... That he..... Should..... Pro-nounce..... Each..... Word..... Se-parate-ly..... Because..... The..... Spa-ces..... Can..... Be..... Ta-ken..... Out..... La-ter..... Right.....? Except the sound engineer either didn't know how or couldn't be bothered. Whoever recorded those lines needs to stay far away from microphones in the future. 

The protagonist's VOs were good. The other characters were tolerable for the most part. I just wish they didn't make all the African locals sound like suburban white people. The core story is generic enough that you could redraw the characters as WASPs, change a couple of voodoo-specific terms to Westernised 'seance' crap and the game could easily take place in Florida or London or something.

[h1]To Sum Up[/h1]
I'm b*tching a lot, I know. I'm technically on the fence about it overall. But what tipped it to positive is that in the end I honestly didn't feel like I wanted my 3 hours back. This game probably requires a good bit of patience for the various "wtf do I do now" moments, but if you find this title in your backlog and are looking for a cheap distraction, it's not the worst way to spend a few hours. 

(My longer playtime seems to be from idling - actual playtime is about 2 hours and change.)

review:
I'll put this out there right from the start: this game is awful. I've played a lot of HO games because they don't require a long commitment and they're often a nice change of pace from the shooters and action games that I normally play. This game belongs on the left edge of the bell curve.

(Yes, I know that this game is five years old, but when Steam asks if I recommend it, I don't care about its age. I do NOT recommend this!)

The voice acting is atrocious. It's ridiculously bad. The main narrator isn't too bad, to be honest. The little girl really *is* a little girl, not an adult putting on a fake kid's voice, and she's actually pretty good, too. The rest -- holy sweet jumping Jesus. They're AWFUL! One of the first characters you meet pauses every other word. No, I'm not kidding. "Pathetic" doesn't come close to the voice actor. The one character is supposed to be older yet her voice actress made her sound quite young. Another character is a young guy but his voice actor must have been in his 50s or more. There is a disconnect between the characters and their voice actors unlike any HO game I've ever played. 

And then to top it all off, the game takes place in sub-Saharan Africa yet only one of the native characters you meet will have any semblance of an accent. With my US locale, all but that one spoke with American English. In sub-Saharan Africa? Are you f-ing kidding me?

The puzzles aren't difficult, but I ran into one issue where a number 3 was supposed to be shaded on a book cover -- except it wasn't there. The game glitched and made the 3 invisible. I had no choice but to use a hint. So much for the no hint achievement, but I had no other choice.

The story is bad. Really bad. And things happen in the game that seem to have no connection with the previous scene. The reason for the main baddie isn't given until near the end, but her presence is still barely explained, and it's never explained why she's a threat nor was any history given. She's there; she's evil; and that's about it. The story is so disjointed that any semblance of a plot is superficial at best.

I never skipped any of the cutscenes; yet scenes seemed to jump from one scenario to another -- and I never got the achievement to watch all cutscenes. So apparently that's glitched, too.

The only good thing about this is that you get Steam cards. But if they're of no interest to you, skip this game all together. There are so many other HO games out there that are superior, but this game is so awful that "superior" is not a high bar to jump.

Again, I know this game is five years old but I couldn't possibly recommend this except for those who want easy Steam cards, those who are masochists, or both. Seriously. F**k this game.

review:
[h1]The Saint: Abyss of Despair[/h1]
...is a hidden object game. Retired from the army, former-priest John is summoned to Africa by his cousin who believes his daughter is possessed and hopes John can exorcise her.

[h1]‚öô [u]Game Description & Mechanics[/u] ‚öô[/h1]
As with other hidden object game, you move from one area panel to another, picking up clues to the stories and items you'll need to interact or unlock further areas, or solving various puzzles to open doors, boxes, or finding objects.

Puzzles consists, of course, of the genre namesake Hidden Object puzzles: you have a scene filled with trinkets and objects of all kinds, and you must find the items described on the list at the bottom of the screen. Other puzzles include connecting dots, moving objects on the screen into a specific pattern, or accomplishing a multi-step task by using items in the right order.

[h1]‚ò∫ [u]What I enjoyed[/u] ‚ò∫[/h1]
While simple, the story is the usual strange and supernatural style you come to expect from the genre, and the story evolves more as your character slip in and out of dreams, go to additional locations and interact with a few people.

It's always nice to see the hand-drawn style of the panels of each area of hidden object scenes. The objects look indistinguishable from the background, so you can't just figure out which object need to be removed at a glance. For those that are having a harder time, an easier difficulty level is available, as well as a hint system, or the option of skipping some puzzles.

[h1]‚òπ [u]What bothered me[/u] ‚òπ[/h1]
Graphics are based on a 4x3 low resolution that looks pixelated and blurry when stretched over a modern widescreen high-resolution monitor. But cutscenes and animations are what really show the game's age. And while at first the narrator didn't sound too bad, you'll quickly see how awful, dare I say pathetic at times, the voice acting is.

There are very few puzzles, and they are extremely simple. It won't take you long to figure them out, most in a single try. The hidden object scenes have no randomization, nothing special to them. Except perhaps for the last act, almost any item you find are for immediate use, so don't expect to hoard a bunch of items and having to attempt figuring their usefulness out.

Nothing you'll find in this game is unique, it's an extremely bare-bone run-of-the-mill hidden object game. There are very few areas to visit, few puzzles and hidden object scenes at all, and the game will be over before you know it.

[h1][b]My Verdict[/b]: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ - [i]"Forget it."[/i][/h1]

This game is way too basic to really stand out. There are so many better games of the genre out there. If you have it in your Steam catalog, take a few hours to get it over with. Otherwise, you should seriously put your money somewhere else if you're shopping for a hidden object game.

[h1]Short version: 32%[/h1]
This hidden object game had a great premise with the plot about a priest‚Äôs haunted niece and the colonial African setting, but it is just too tedious to enjoy.

[h1]Long version:[/h1]
The Saint: Abyss of Despair manages to present one of the oldest hidden object clich√©s in an interesting new way: we play as a former soldier and priest, visiting a cousin in colonial Africa to save his little daughter who was seemingly possessed by a demon. From here, the story follows the pacing of a classic British crime novel, with the supernatural and the local belief system (plus bad voice acting) playing a dominant role in the events.

The player has to work hard to watch this story though, because the game is incredibly tedious. You must revisit every area after completing any task, since many hotspots only activate after certain triggers. Some key items do not change the cursor, so it is easy to miss them. The puzzles are easy but take forever, and hit detection during hidden object scenes is wonky at best.
No matter how good the story is, all of these problems are just too great to recommend the game to anyone.

review:
This rough around the edges supernatural mystery, point and click come hidden object game is a mediocre affair at best. Graphics appear fixed at 1024 x 768 which on a 1080p, 24" monitor results in slightly blury and washed out image but should be bearable to those of us with a receeding hairline. The story is ok, how it is conveyed however makes it entirely forgettable and lacking in atmosphere or suspense. While there is voice acting present it is best described as amauerish and in more than one instance, slightly offensive at least to those of a PC principal persuasion.

Best bought dirt cheap or in a bundle as it provides at best a couple of hours of time wastage (I dare not quite say entertainment), easier to reccomend to those of a trading card / chieveo / easy 100% hunting nature.

review:
I feel like they ran out of money for this game. Towards the end their are 4 puzzles that are exactly the same  they only changed the face on the coin. The exact same puzzle. When you get to the end of the game your treated to a black screen with  your person just reading some text about what happened. Lack of money. 

The puzzles are mostly terrible. Some of them have no room to move the pieces around. The voice acting is all over the place. Your character is voiced good. The people you meet are terrible voiced. I think one guy did not know how to speak english so he over pronounced every single word and talked super slow. So.....he...talked.....very....slowly.....

The story starts out strong and then goes off the rails. Your trying to help a girl who has been taken over by a spirit. 

Stuff happens in here that makes no sense. You have to give an antidote. However you never see the  person taking it even though you make it. Your put sleeping pills inside a soda that you give to a cop. Fairly certain thats a felony. Not only that you also forge a pass by using that cops name. Even though I finished the game I am still a little confused by the ending. 

The game is short. I finished it in under 3 hours. The graphics I did enjoy. The sounds in the game including the music were good. The story is just a mess. Things happen for no logical reasons. I am torn on this review. I did finish the game. So I did enjoy it. However the ending is just blah. Overall I am going to give it a thumbs up for the graphics and the sound in the game.
